title: Coordinator/Any Campus Staff Position Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at SMU (Southern Methodist University) in Nov 2016
Interview Descriptions:
This place is the worst! The interview process is so antiquated it is not even funny. I have applied to over 20 positions over the previous four years via their HR website and each time has been a very unpleasant experience. 

The ATS system does not allow you to log in to check the status of any pending applications because after you have applied. It is never updated until you are no longer being considered for the job. 

If a department likes you after HR has forwarded your information to them, you will typically be selected for “pre-screening” where you are asked the general questions below. 

Sometimes question 2 will be worded differently and the department will ask you what you feel the starting salary range is for the position applied. With the recent changes in employment law with FSLA, I recommend always saying the minimum salary is at least $48,000. Many “classified” university positions should at least be at this starting level unless you have to track your actual hours worked. 

If you indicate more for a starting salary, the departments will no longer consider you for the position. Do not try and get a higher salary initially even if you have more than enough of relevant experience and more that just the minimum required level of education. At SMU they try and get employees to start working there for the lowest salary possible and then give them about a 1.5%-3.0% raise annually for cost of living. Sadly many new employees will accept the lower salary to “get their foot in the door” and move to another department or leave SMU after approximately 1.5 years. SMU is the worst!
Interview Questions:
1.  What qualifications do you have that uniquely fit the job description in the posting?

2.  The salary range for this position in the current budget year is between $XX,XXX and $XX,XXX. Would this salary prevent you from further consideration of the position?
	
3.  When would you be available to start the position if you are selected as the finalist? 

4.  Describe an event you have planned. Include details about the scope of the event and size of the audience.  Include any comments about the budget you had for planning and ways you managed your team to stay within budget and succeed with the goals of the event.

5.  Tell me about a time when you showed initiative to solve a problem at work or to initiate processes that would improve the workplace and/or work flow.

6.  If you are an out-of-town candidate, we are unable to pay relocation or travel expenses. Would this prevent you from taking the position if you were the finalist?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at SMU (Southern Methodist University) (Dallas, TX)

The in person interview is a breeze if you just smile and act very confident. If you're working in Student Affairs, the people interviewing you will not be very bright. They like to do everything in groups to make it appear to be more intimidating and like they make decisions as a group. Everything in SMU Student Affairs is very collective, but you will find that it is just a facade. The boss of whatever center, department, etc. makes the decision with a huge committee or panel of people under them that serve to create the appearance that their collective analyses of the information results in the decision. In reality, they do little to nothing but have meetings and take minutes...with each meeting not improving on the previous one and the minutes looking identical with a few minute changes. Whatever boss A decides to do will happen and the committee will simply create a sense that the decision was made as a group. It's very odd.

Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview with 2-3 people at once, and then an in person interview with five people. They were very friendly and the questions were pretty standard. They took turns answering a set of 5-7 questions and then allowed me time to ask questions. I was interviewed by faculty and one other staffer. They actually ended up originally hiring my competitor and then I got a call when that didn't work out, and was hired.
Interview Questions: Name a time you didn't get along with a co-worker and had to resolve a conflict. What is one of your weaknesses?

title: Tutor Interview

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at SMU (Southern Methodist University) (Dallas, TX) in Apr 2012
Interview Descriptions: They flew me into Dallas, got picked up, stayed at a hotel, got fed the next day and talked with all of the faculty in my department that were available.  By the end of the day they had an offer ready for me for graduate tuition support and a graduate research stipend.
Interview Questions: The biggest question they had was if I had a research project in mind for my thesis/dissertation.  They also asked why I applied as an MSc and not a PhD.

title: Senior Manager, Employer Relations- Cox School of Business, MBA Programs Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at SMU (Southern Methodist University) (Dallas, TX) in Sept 2011
Interview Descriptions:
FULL day interview process with no less than 6 different areas affiliated with the Cox school. I was interviewed by at least 20 people (some in small groups, some as individual interviews) over the course of a single day.  It was a 2-round interview process that involved making the final round and having to interview with 1-2 administrative personnel and a group of MBA students to close the deal.

The students were pretty easy to converse with, but the dean-level interviews were tough.  Candidates should know the Cox School rankings- and history of rankings (for ALL MBA-level offerings) very well- and be able to state why they can improve upon those rankings given the competition of other schools in their category.  You have got to show definitive outcomes and measurable results for getting this job.  You should be able to discuss a personal 30-90 day strategy to be utilized post-hire.   (GREAT RESULTS/OUTCOMES=HIGHER PROGRAM RANKINGS)
Interview Questions: Why are you the BEST candidate for this role?    What experiences do you bring to this role that would assist our many MBA candidates who seek both internships and jobs post graduation?  What would your strategic plan look like in the first 30 days- the first 90 days?  How many contacts do you have with Fortune 250 companies that hire MBA candidates- and in which functional areas?  How would you deal with a situation involving a student who rejects a confirmed/agreed upon offer with Company "A" once the student leverages said offer with Company "B"?

title: Fire Safety Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at SMU (Southern Methodist University) (Dallas, TX) in May 2011
Interview Descriptions: Process consisted of a phone interview asking about my knowledge of the University and about 5 basic interview questions. That was followed by an in person interview with a board of 5 members. This was more technical with each board member being a person I would interact with regularly on the job. Then I had a follow up in person interview with another 5 interview board members who comprised the office that I would work in.
Interview Questions: Interview was very heavy on technical experience and ability to manage difficult situations. Questions change with each job opening.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
